awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of nontraditional washers and dryers. People living in rural areas including Alaska, often cite water as a scarce resource and often visit a washateria/laundromat or haul water to wash their clothing. Many homes do not have the water hookups needed for a washing machine, and it often takes a day to do laundry by hand. Current laundry appliances rely on large-scale mechanical agitation for washing and heat-driven evaporation of retained water for drying. The average washing machine uses 20 gallons of water to operate and uses hot and cold water hook-ups for operation. The standard dryer requires a 240-volt dedicated circuit. Clothes dryers account for 6% of residential energy usage and are responsible for 40 million metric tons of annual carbon dioxide emissions. The proposed technology leverages ultrasound to reduce the energy and water consumption of home laundry appliances while combining the processes into one low-cost appliance. These factors not only reduce the cost of ownership but make the proposed appliance more accessible to smaller dwellings.

This I-Corps project is based on the development of an accessible, all-in-one ultrasonic washer and dryer to save time, space, and resources in environments that lack the traditional infrastructure for washers and dryers. The core technology is an ultrasonic transducer array that enables washing and drying to be performed with less energy and water in a single, compact appliance. Ultrasound is used to drive the creation of bubbles. Upon collapse, they generate a localized force and heat which gently expels dirt out of clothing. In the drying process, the technology uses ultrasonic atomization to cut drying time and use less power, allowing for the use of a standard wall outlet.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Ultropia's NSF I-Corps project focused on validating an innovative ultrasound drying technology designed to improve energy efficiency and performance in industrial and commercial laundry operations. Laundry drying processes represent substantial energy consumption and environmental challenges. The structured NSF I-Corps training enabled our team to conduct rigorous market research and over 100 customer discovery interviews, affirming strong market demand for ultrasound-enhanced drying technologies capable of significantly reducing energy use and drying time.

Through the NSF I-Corp program we able to articulate the value proposition of our technology and better understand the needs of our potential customers. The needs of our potential customers are echoed in the 2022 San Diego Regional Decarbonization Framework’s Technical Report states, “Commercial laundry systems face higher barriers to the adoption of electric options than do residential. Running many large electric dryers, as in a laundromat, could require substantial upgrades to a building’s electrical system if it is transitioning from gas equipment. The slower speed of heat pump dryers is also more of a challenge in throughput-limited commercial laundry systems than in residential applications”. By understanding the needs of the industry, Ultropia refined the requirement of our development to produce an easily integrable laundry-specific ultrasound array to support the electrification of the $5.3 billion commercial laundry market. The benefits align with laundry facility operators' needs by reducing energy costs by as much 80% and improving processing times by as much as 50%. The resulting cost savings for facilities helps promote the use of reusable linens and shifts demand from disposables. State-of-the-art laundry systems rely on mechanical agitation and evaporative drying. Power ultrasound enables efficient energy transfer for the washing and drying processes, reducing energy usage by as much as 80% while increasing linen throughput. 

The NSF I-Corps experience facilitated meaningful connections with key industry stakeholders. We joined the Textile Rental Services Association (TRSA), enabling direct engagement with industry leaders. We are able to connect with local facilities that were excited to have a voice in the development of the technology and offered resources like industrial-scale dryer for validation testing. We were also able to tour several industrial facilities like K-Bro Linen Systems, Sterile Surgical Solutions, MediCleanse, and NOVO Health Services Plant.

Throughout the project, our team enhanced critical professional skills. Amy Swanson, the Entrepreneurial Lead, and Cody Birkland, the Technical Lead, expanded their engineering expertise to encompass entrepreneurial leadership and market-driven innovation. Amy further supported entrepreneurial education as the Entrepreneur-in-Residence at the University of Washington's Women's Entrepreneurial Leadership program, mentoring aspiring female entrepreneurs. Cody actively contributed insights from the project to support technical teams and emerging entrepreneurs in the local innovation community.

Institutionally, our efforts were supported by the University of Washington’s technology transfer office, CoMotion, which provided essential administrative assistance to ensure smooth grant management and sustained project progress. Additionally, digital tools such as LinkedIn Premium, Notion, and Otter.ai enhanced our research and communication capabilities, strengthening Ultropia’s internal processes for effective market engagement and analysis.

Overall, Ultropia's NSF I-Corps journey successfully validated a promising business model, refined market-driven technological solutions, and established a clear pathway toward commercialization. The broader impacts extend well beyond engineering, offering significant environmental and economic benefits by reducing energy costs, enhancing operational efficiency, and supporting sustainability initiatives within the laundry industry.

 

 


Last Modified: 04/02/2025
Modified by: Ashlee Esteban-Akimoto
